title: How bad is a Squier Telecaster? - Quora

response.answer_text: Tone and play-ability varies from guitar to guitar, year to year and country to country. There’s so much you can do to make a guitar great and top tier Squier’s are generally decent guitars. I have taken guitars apart and the two Chinese Squier CV50’s in my possession had alder wood parts glued together to make a guitar body. One sounded okay and the other thin. The necks are decent if you’re not gigging with it night after night, remove the tremolo (if it’s a strat, you don’t have to worry about that on a tele) and know how to do a fret job, how to set up a guitar with shim, nut, etc. That knowledge is just a few youtube videos and googles away. On CV50’s and Classic Vibes the tuners are decent. The electronics hiss more than they should. They use an electronic switch I’m not fond of, but switches are cheap and wiring diagrams are free. Just google “tele wiring diagrams”. Some folks don’t believe in tone wood and that’s fine. Just change the pickups. Soldering is easy. Plenty of videos on how to solder. Some of the stock pickups are pretty good, especially if you change the capacitors. I happen to like dark capacitors 1uf in my tele’s and strat’s and brighter ones in my Gibson’s. Some years Squier has been almost on par with Fender MIA (Protone Cort Factory Made In Korea 1996–1998) and some years they’re awful. I’m not a fan of most Chinese guitars but there are Made in America and Made in Japan Squiers that are amazing. Again, if you use youtube, google, and are willing to invest time, effort and money (dowel’s, sandpaper, tape, files, black markers, steel wool) you can make a Squier Tele into an excellent player guitar almost on par with many Made in Mexico guitars. The key is to get low action, soft frets with rounded soft corners. It’s time consuming but not as hard as it sounds. Good luck and have fun!

Loaded question. Squier guitars are excellent value, most of the time. Buying a squier strat with a cheap squier amp, or one of those packages that has a gig bag and other accessories, is a tremendously good idea for new guitarists. If you’re a parent with a child interested in guitar, consider this because of the value. If your kid is still playing in a few years and is pretty good, then think about a nicer guitar or larger amp maybe. I own several guitars and have been playing since 8 or 9, my guitar was a squier strat and I played that exclusively until I bought an American strat and a Gibson LP in my mid 20s when I had the means to do so. No, you’re not going to get a warm, bold tone from a squier guitar and amp, but it’s good enough until you actually know what you’re doing.

Why phrase the question that way? It sounds like you’ve already decided before you’ve asked. The “Vintage Modified” and “Classic Vibe” line are very consistently good guitars throughout the Squier range. I noodled on a Vintage Modified Jazzmaster last time I was in my local shop - pretty impressive. The “Standard” series are usually perfectly serviceable. I would steer clear of the “Affinity” and the rock-bottom “Bullet” series, not because they cannot also be good guitars, but because they are probably going to require service (fret leveling / crowning and setup) to play as well as the Standard. Really it just comes down to whether you want a brand-new guitar or not. You can get a new Squier Classic Vibe Tele for about what a used Mexican made Fender costs.

Great value, all things considered. But as with any mass produced guitars, some will be better than others, which you can only know by trying them out. I know several professionals that use Squires, albeit with upgraded electronics and professional setup, (I prefer Vintage Vibe Guitars for replacement parts on mine) leaving their more valuable guitars at home when they’re on the road.

Not bad to pretty good. The lowest end ones are not bad, but not really something to gig with unless you’re absolutely strapped for cash. The highest end ones are excellent guitars for the price and have become the choice of some guitarists who don’t care about the Fender branding.
The Squire is no worse than any other Chinese guitar—but in inexpensive guitars, a MIM Fender Stratocaster is a much better way to go.
I have a Squier standard tele in my collection. Don't see it going anywhere.
